As a recent Cuban immigrant, I read Mirta Ojito's article (April 23) with a painful feeling of understanding. However, the last two paragraphs of the article prompted me to write this letter.

I was in Cuba when President Clinton's ''remarkable policy shift'' took place. For many young Cubans of my generation, escaping -- one way or another -- was the only feasible way of openly saying no and rejecting the regime. The remote possibility of reaching Florida's shore on a raft kept our hopes alive.

I agree that the American government should not allow Fidel Castro to use the ''Mariel scenario'' to blackmail the United States. But by returning Cuban rafters at a moment when internal tensions were reaching a climax (remember the uprising in Havana that summer), the Clinton administration showed the real American policy toward Cuba: indifference.
I remember the feeling of resignation that fell on us like a heavy sunset. We were left alone. The illusion that up north, somewhere, somebody cared was gone.
